report_title: Investment Banking & Securities Dealing in the US
executive_summary: Strong returns in various financial markets and increased trading volumes have benefited operators in the Investment Banking and Securities Dealing industry over the five years to 2022. Operators provide underwriting, originating and market-making services for a range of financial instruments, including bonds, stocks and derivatives. During the majority of the period, industry operators benefited from improving macroeconomic conditions and interest rates remaining below historical averages. This led to increased demand for industry operators' services during the period. Overall, industry revenue has increased an annualized 8.5% to $182.5 billion over the five years to 2022, including an expected increase of 17.6% in 2022 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Largely stemming from strong demand for IPOs, industry revenue has increased at an annualized rate of 8.5% to $182.5 billion over the five years, including an expected increase of 17.6% in 2022 alone.
Increased volatility in financial markets as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic has led to increased trading and investment-grade debt activity for industry operators.
Equity underwriting activity and the total value of IPOs has increased in recent years, benefiting industry revenue. Secondary equity offerings and SPACs have also been popular.
Debt underwriting has increased as businesses have turned to industry operators to help raise cash during the pandemic.
Smaller investment banks have increasingly begun to focus on providing M&A advising services, which do not require as much scale.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The industry is forecast to continue growing over the five years to 2027, albeit at a slower rate of 3.7% annually.
Improving financial market conditions will likely spur higher corporate activity and demand for equity underwriting and M&A services.
The Federal Reserve is expected to increase interest rates, enabling industry operators to earn higher interest income on loans.
However, industry operators may generate less trading revenue as volatility dissipates and investor uncertainty declines.
Industry employment is forecast to rise 3.6% annually, but wages will remain high due to competition for skilled workers.

industry_definition: This industry is composed of companies and individuals that provide a range of securities services, including investment banking and broker-dealer trading services. They also offer banking and wealth management services and engage in proprietary trading (trading their own capital for a profit) to varying degrees. Investment banking services include securities underwriting and corporate financial services, while trading services include market making and broker-dealer services.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: high - increasing

key_trends: Lower interest rates led borrowers to seek industry services to underwrite debt offerings
Smaller investment banks have increasingly shifted to M&A advising services
Industry operators are expected to benefit from rising interest rates on loans made
Improving financial markets will spur demand for equity underwriting and M&A services
Regulation of the financial sector will likely increase in the United States and Europe
Industry operators have benefited from increased trading activity on behalf of their clients

market_segmentation.segment_description: Financial operators like banks, insurance companies, brokerages use investment banks for underwriting, lending, advisory services.
Non-financial businesses use investment banks for underwriting equity/debt, hedging risks, lending, advisory services.
Technology companies use investment banks for mergers/acquisitions and selling startups to larger corporations.
Healthcare companies use investment banking services.
Industrial companies use investment banking services.
Energy and power companies use investment banking services.

products_and_services.product_description: Investment banks serve as middlemen between companies looking to raise funds by securitizing debt to be traded to investors in exchange for capital.
Investment banks conduct sales, trading, custodian, financing and market-making activities on securities, futures exchanges and other markets.
Investment banks assist companies wishing to go public by issuing common stock, preferred stock and other equity-related securities.

Financial advisory services include strategic advisory assignments with respect to mergers and acquisitions, divestitures, corporate defense activities, risk management, restructurings, spin-offs, exchange offers and shareholder relations.
Other products and services offered by investment banks.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand broadly depends on factors such as interest rates, business earnings, investor confidence, uncertainty in the market and regulatory changes.
Demand reflects the level of capital raising and business investment, including initial public offerings, bonds, and structured products.
Trading volume is related to stock market performance, investor uncertainty and performance of alternative investments.

business_locations.location_description: The Mid-Atlantic region remains the most important geographical market, with New York having 15% of establishments.
The Southeast region has seen the fastest growth in establishments during the period, driven by population and improving wealth levels.
The West region's share has grown, with California accounting for 13.4% of establishments due to its large population and tech centers.
The Great Lakes region accounts for 12% of establishments.
The Southwest region accounts for 10.1% of establishments.
The New England region accounts for 6.1% of establishments.
The Plains region accounts for 4.3% of establishments.
The Rocky Mountain region accounts for 3.6% of establishments.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Federal Reserve is the supervisor and regulator for bank holding companies, promoting compliance with laws and regulations.
The Bank Holding Company Act regulates entry, structure and activities of bank holding companies through Fed approval.
The Dodd-Frank Act has fundamentally changed how banks operate by affecting financial activities, risk management and oversight.
The Volcker Rule restricts banks from making speculative investments that do not benefit customers, with some recent partial repeal.
Basel III strengthens bank capital, liquidity and leverage requirements, impacting available credit levels and risk management strategies.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Capital and regulatory requirements within the banking sector provide the largest barriers to entry into the Investment Banking and Securities Dealing industry.
Traditional barriers to entry for the industry also include relationships, reputation, economies of scale and research departments that rely on a limited supply of talented labor.
With the increased importance of IT development in the industry and its large initial costs, industry operators have significant barriers to entry for many of the industry's product lines.
The ability to attract a limited supply of skilled labor and pay these individuals accordingly is a very substantial barrier to entry.

basis_points.basis_title: Competition based on fees, services, products and reputation
basis_points.basis_description: Competition within the Investment Banking and Securities Dealing industry is high. Competition is broadly based on the level of fees charged, the range of services and products provided and company-wide reputation.

basis_points.basis_title: Convergence of services offered by players
basis_points.basis_description: There is a trend toward consolidation in the industry and convergence in the services offered by players; the subprime crisis has served only to accelerate this trend.

basis_points.basis_title: Increased size and geographic reach of players
basis_points.basis_description: As the industry consolidates and the range of services broadens into those traditionally offered by other industries, the size and geographic reach of industry players is increasing.

Consolidation and the globalization of capital markets have significantly increased the capital bases of some industry players, bringing US operators into intense competition with large foreign operators that have more capital, a stronger local presence and longer operating histories outside of the United States.

An important point of competition that has emerged since the financial crisis is the ability of investment banks to access funds. Investment banks that rely less on wholesale markets for funding are likely to operate with lower costs, enabling these operators to better compete for business.

concentration_points.concentration_description: One overriding outcome of the great recession has been the rapid consolidation in the market for financial services.

Concentration within the investment banking sector has increased for a myriad of reasons. Many significant players, such as Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers, exited the industry, with existing players purchasing their operations.
Additionally, some major commercial banks have acquired previously independent investment banks, including Bank of America Corporation (BofA), which purchased Merrill Lynch in 2008.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The average industry profit margin, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, is expected to comprise 35.0% of revenue in 2022, up from 25.3% in 2017.

Wages as a share of revenue have decreased during the five-year period, falling from 33.8% in 2017 to 26.4% in 2022 due to operators investing in new technologies and systems that have reduced labor requirements.
Purchase expenses only account for 1.6% of industry revenue in 2022 as operators have increased spending on analytic tools but industry revenue growth has outpaced purchase expense growth.
Depreciation expenses only account for 0.9% of industry revenue in 2022 since operators require little capital assets to conduct business.
Marketing expenses only account for 0.9% of industry revenue in 2022 as most customers seek out industry operators on their own.
Rental expenses are expected to account for 1.9% of industry revenue in 2022 as businesses only need office space to conduct their services.
Utility expenses will account for 0.1% of industry revenue in 2022.

Other costs like brokering, clearing, exchange fees, insurance, hedging, administration, IT systems, legal and compliance costs have increased during the period, particularly provisions for losses and compliance costs.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: IBISWorld estimates that for every $1.00 spent on wages, the industry will allocate $0.04 to capital investment.
Wages represent the largest single expense at 26.4% of revenue in 2022 as the industry relies extensively on talented labor.
Industry participants have increasingly invested in technology to improve efficiency and lower processing and administrative costs during the five-year period.

volatility_points.volatility_description: IBISWorld expects revenue volatility to reach 3.6% in 2022, depending on changes in fees and trading gains based on macroeconomic conditions.
Industry revenue tends to follow the financial market cycle very closely, performing well in good economic conditions and poorly in downturns.
The leveraging activities used by many operators increase the industry's revenue volatility by multiplying gains and losses.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Investment banks with advanced trading systems will attract the most liquidity and offer the most competitive rates.
Introduction of new computer software has enabled streamlining of back office administration and reduction of costs.
Expected technological changes will provide greater control over trading activities and legislation compliance over the next five years.

FAQs.question: How do you emphasize the value of your company's services?
FAQs.answer: By cultivating a relationship with clients, an investment bank can get a better understanding of a client's needs and supply them with the proper products. Having deep understandings of their clients operating conditions and business needs helped banks specifically tailor products to help their clients weather turbulent financial conditions during the COVID-19 pandemic.

FAQs.question: How diversified are your product offerings compared to competitors?
FAQs.answer: Products offered by investment banks generally varies based upon the size of the bank. Smaller banks look to provide advisory services, as it is not capital intensive and based on relationships, while bulge bracket banks provide wholesale investment banking services. In 2020 and 2021, banks that specialized in executing clients' trades, as well as underwriting debt, benefitted from volatility in financial markets and companies looking to raise cash to weather the COVID-19 pandemic.

FAQs.question: What is your company doing to reduce costs?
FAQs.answer: Investment banks have tried to automate varies process in recent years to cut costs and increase efficiencies. For example, trading services and trade execution have been an area banks have automated in recent years. Automation, and by extension cost savings, of these services materialized in 2020 and 2021 as a result of increased trading volumes stemming from volatility brought on by the COVID-19 pandemic.

FAQs.question: What international operations do you conduct and how could benefit from increasing your international reach?
FAQs.answer: Only large investment banks have the economy of scales needed to operate globally. Having the ability to operate internationally helps banks diversify risk associate with any one market. Banks with global operations were able to service a broader client base in 2020 and 2021, helping them stabilize their business during the COVID-19 pandemic.

FAQs.question: What new IT and data systems have you invested into in recent years?
FAQs.answer: New data driven systems have been implemented by investment banks to help employees further analyze data, while also reducing the labor intensity of the work employees conduct. Investment in these technologies also helped bankers seamlessly transition to remote working during the COVID-19 pandemic as well.

FAQs.question: To what extent are your processes automated and how do you plan on investing in automation over the coming years?
FAQs.answer: While certain investment banking services cannot be automated, activities like trading and trade execution have been automated in recent years to cut costs and increase accuracy. Automation of trading services proved to be beneficial for some operators during the COVID-19 pandemic, as it brought with it increased trading volumes stemming from greater investor uncertainty.

FAQs.question: How do you expect the proposed changes to Dodd-Frank to effect your business?
FAQs.answer: Dodd-Frank has had widespread effects on investment banks. One such example has been the Volcker Rule which restricts investment banks from proprietarily trading securities on a short-term basis. In 2020, certain aspects of the Volcker Rule were eased and banks were again allowed to invest in venture capital funds.

FAQs.question: How have the increased capital requirements under Basel III affected operations?
FAQs.answer: While Basel III has increased the stability of investment banks, it has also cut into banks profitability. This has hurt investors valuations of banks as well. In 2020, some provisions regarding transactions were removed from the Basel framework.

FAQs.question: What methods have you adopted to improve cash flow in recent years?
FAQs.answer: Investment banks have started to provide ancillary financial services, such as wealth management, to supplement their core investment banking services and improve cash flow. Additionally, offering a suite of investment banking services such as different types of equity and debt underwriting, along with advisory and other services has helped to diversify revenue streams and improve cash flow.

FAQs.question: How does your profit margin compare to those of your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Investment banks' profit margins vary based on the size of the bank and the type of banking services they provide. In 2020, investment banks profitability benefitted from increased demand for debt underwriting and trade execution services, but was hindered by expected losses incurred during the COVID-19 pandemic.

FAQs.question: What measures do you take to retain highly skilled laborers? Have your strategies for retention changed as a result of increased regulation?
FAQs.answer: An experienced and highly trained staff is necessary for this industry. Clients are attracted to individuals and teams that have successfully raised debt and equity in the past. A key to retaining talent has continued to be compensation of workers, especially performance-related compensation.

FAQs.question: How do you ensure your employees are tending to their portfolios? How can this be demonstrated to potential investors?
FAQs.answer: The ability to provide quality research is one skillset will attract more investors to buy securities. The ability to easily convey certain aspects of a portfolio to clients is another. Additionally, diversifying clients' portfolios to properly benefit from volatility in certain asset classes at different times, especially times of financial uncertainty like the COVID-19 pandemic has caused, is yet another desirable skillset.

FAQs.question: What steps will you take to cater to the consumers' needs? How will you raise sufficient funds to maximize returns?
FAQs.answer: It is essential to have the right mix of product offerings that raise sufficient funds on the sell side to maximize returns on the buy side.

FAQs.question: How has the current number of initial public offerings affected your company? How can you adapt as the number of initial public offerings declines?
FAQs.answer: Investment banks help companies raise capital by underwriting their first sale of stock (equity) to public investors. A high number of IPOs represents increased business demand for capital, which leads to higher underwriting revenue for the industry. In 2020, many companies delayed their plans to go public as a result of financial uncertainty caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Many of these companies sought alternative forms of funding through either debt issuance or through additional private investment. In 2021, as economic activity begins to normalize as concerns surround the pandemic wane, financial stability is expected to increase leading the value of IPOs to return to pre-pandemic levels.

FAQs.question: How will you capitalize on increasing corporate profit?
FAQs.answer: Changes in corporate profit influence the performance of equities markets because they affect how companies are valued, which in turn influences trading and business activity. In 2020 and 2021, corporate profitability has varied widely across sectors, leading investment banks to benefit from a sharp uptick in the total number of trades they have executed for clients in those years.

FAQs.question: Do you diversify your asset portfolios? How do you respond to an increasing S&P?
FAQs.answer: When equities markets are performing well, the industry generates more revenue from trading activities and experiences increased demand from downstream clients for strategic advisory services. Despite considerable volatility due to financial uncertainty cause by the COVID-19 pandemic, the value of the S&P 500 increased in 2020 and is expected to continue to increase in 2021 as well.
